variant.question: Assuming the same runway and associated conditions, which statement below best describes the reason for the differences between the performance figures produced by the modern performance software in an Electronic Flight Bag (EFB), when compared to those derived from the Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) tables?

options.text: The RTOW tables are typically older and therefore NOT suitable for use in a modern aeroplane where a lot of processes are automated.
Performance figures from the RTOW tables are more conservative as they include a safety factor of 1.15 that is NOT applied in the EFB calculations.
EFB calculations are more accurate and will therefore produce more conservative performance figures than retrieved from RTOW tables.
The EFB figures are more accurate because a computer is able to consider more accurate parameters and apply these without interpolation.

variant.question: A pilot preparing for a flight has manually extracted the relevant figures from the aircraft performance charts. They then cross-check these figures with the ones produced by the software on their EFB, and see differences in the results. What might have caused these results to vary from each other?

options.text: The EFB is more accurate as it does not need to interpolate any parameters.
The tables include an extra safety factor of 1.5.
The tables are no longer accurate for aircraft with such a high level of automation.
The EFB is more accurate and its outputs are more conservative.
